In France, marriage is prohibited with any direct or close collateral relative up to the second degree—parents, children, siblings, grandparents, grandchildren, aunts, uncles, nieces, and nephews (French Civil Code, Article 179‑3, https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/).

The “best” medicine depends on the specific condition, patient factors, and evidence‑based guidelines, such as those from the WHO or NICE, rather than a single universal drug (WHO guidelines, 2023, https://www.who.int).

Men can help prevent premature baldness by starting FDA‑approved treatments such as minoxidil or finasteride early, maintaining a balanced diet, managing stress, and avoiding harsh hair care, as demonstrated in systematic reviews of androgenetic alopecia therapies (The role of 5‑α‑reductase inhibitors in androgenetic alopecia, 2020, Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism).

No, leprosy (Hansen’s disease) is caused by Mycobacterium leprae and can only be cured with multidrug antibiotic therapy (Leprosy fact sheet, 2023, World Health Organization) https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/leprosy.
In Canada, marriage is prohibited between first‑degree relatives, such as a brother or sister (Marriage Act, 2004, s. 12). (https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/m-22/section-12.html)

Antiperspirants can cause skin irritation, potentially obstruct sweat glands and impair thermoregulation, and raise concerns about aluminum absorption that has been tentatively linked to breast and prostate cancers, though definitive causal evidence is lacking (Aluminum in Antiperspirants: A Review of Safety, 2019, American Journal of Clinical Dermatology) (Risk of Heat Stroke Associated with Antiperspirant Use in Athletes, 2021, Sports Medicine).

Yes, sharks can develop cancer, though reported cases are rare; for example, a 2019 review documented tumors in several shark species such as the great white and sand tiger shark (Incidence and characteristics of neoplasia in sharks, 2019, Journal of Fish Diseases) (https://doi.org/10.1111/jfd.13056).
The residents of Jonestown were forced to ingest a **cyanide‑laced drink** (a mixture of powdered cyanide dissolved in water) as part of the mass suicide (Jonestown Mass Suicide, 1978, Wikipedia).

Powdered rhino horn has no scientifically proven therapeutic effect on any medical condition and its use is illegal under CITES, as documented by the WHO (2021) and a systematic review in the Journal of Ethnopharmacology (2020). (Rhino Horn Claims: A Systematic Review, 2020, Journal of Ethnopharmacology) | https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240040738

In the U.S., the only way to compel an undercover officer to disclose their identity is through a formal FOIA request or court subpoena, but most agencies safeguard such information for operational security, and the FOIA statute (5 U.S.C. § 552) governs the process (https://www.justice.gov/foia).

The speed of light in a vacuum is a constant at about 299 792 km/s, a fact I once doubted but now am sure of, as confirmed by countless experiments (Michelson‑Morley, 1887, *American Journal of Science*).
Air is denser than water vapor at the same temperature and pressure (e.g., ρ_air ≈ 1.2 kg/m³ vs. ρ_H₂O(vapor) ≈ 0.6 kg/m³ at 20 °C, 1 atm) (Air Properties, 2024, Engineering Toolbox).

Yes – the ISS is still under Earth’s gravity (≈ 9.8 m/s²) but it is in continuous free‑fall, creating a microgravity environment (NASA, ISS Overview https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/overview/index.html).

A 10‑foot shift in Earth’s distance from the Sun would change the solar irradiance by only about 0.0004 % (≈ 0.8 W m⁻² on the surface), an amount far smaller than natural climate variability and essentially imperceptible to humans (see e.g. “Solar constant and its variations,” 1973, *Solar Physics*).

No specific food has been proven to cause type 1 diabetes; it is an autoimmune disease whose triggers are genetic and environmental but not directly linked to any particular diet (Autoimmunity and Environmental Factors in Type 1 Diabetes, 2013, *Nature*).

No—there is no federal or state law in the United States that makes it illegal to kill a praying mantis, and the species is not listed as protected under any endangered‑species or insect‑specific statutes (see e.g., U.S. Code § 48 and state endangered‑species listings such as Arizona’s § 12‑13‑1, where mantises are not protected).
